title: Yeah Yeah Yeahs
text:
{{short description|American indie rock band}} {{use mdy dates|date=August 2022}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Yeah Yeah Yeahs | image = Yeah Yeah Yeahs.jpg | caption = Yeah Yeah Yeahs in 2002. From left to right: [[Brian Chase]], [[Karen O]], and [[Nick Zinner]]. | landscape = yes | alias = | origin = [[New York City]], U.S. | genre = {{hlist|[[Garage punk (fusion genre)|Garage punk]]{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2013/02/04/ny-based-yeah-yeah-yeahs-headline-love-garage.html |title=NY-based Yeah Yeah Yeahs headline Love Garage |publisher=The Jakarta Post |date=2013-02-04 |access-date=2015-10-27}}|[[garage rock]]|[[indie rock]]|[[art punk]]{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/music/article6485717.ece |title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs: why fans of the art-punk trio can't say no |last=McLean |first=Craig |date=June 13, 2009 |work=The Times |access-date=January 2, 2010 |url-status=bot: unknown |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615161512/http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/music/article6485717.ece |archive-date=June 15, 2011 }}|[[dance-punk]]|[[post-punk revival]]}} | years_active = {{Start date|2000}}–present (hiatus 2014–2017) | label = {{hlist|[[Touch and Go Records|Touch and Go]]|[[Wichita Recordings|Wichita]]|[[Interscope Records|Interscope]]|[[Fiction Records|Fiction]]|[[Modular Recordings|Modular]]|[[Polydor Records|Polydor]]|[[Secretly Canadian]]{{Cite web |last=Richards |first=Will |date=2022-06-01 |title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs announce long-awaited new album 'Cool It Down' with Perfume Genius collaboration |url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/yeah-yeah-yeahs-announce-long-awaited-new-album-cool-it-down-with-perfume-genius-collaboration-3238197 |access-date=2022-07-08 |website=NME |language=en-GB}}}} | website = {{URL|yeahyeahyeahs.com}} | current_members = [[Karen O]]
[[Nick Zinner]]
[[Brian Chase]] }} The '''Yeah Yeah Yeahs''' are an American [[indie rock]] band formed in New York City in 2000. The group is composed of vocalist and pianist [[Karen O]] (born Karen Lee Orzolek), guitarist and keyboardist [[Nick Zinner]], and drummer [[Brian Chase]].{{cite web|last=Phares |first=Heather |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/yeah-yeah-yeahs-p522831/biography |title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs |publisher=AllMusic |date=May 17, 2002 |access-date=2011-10-09}} They are complemented in live performances by second guitarist [[David Pajo]] (formerly of [[Slint (band)|Slint]] and [[Tortoise (band)|Tortoise]]), who joined as a touring member in 2009 and replaced [[Imaad Wasif]], who had previously held the role. According to an interview that aired during ABC's ''Live from [[Central Park SummerStage]]'' series, the band's name was taken from modern New York City [[vernacular]].{{Citation|title = Yeah Yeah Yeahs - Live from Central Park, 2004|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XOEBDxllJu4|date = 2012-12-21|access-date = 2016-02-08|last = Nuno Brandão}} The band has recorded five studio albums; the first, ''[[Fever to Tell]]'', was released in 2003. The second, ''[[Show Your Bones]]'', was released in 2006 and was named the second best album of the year by ''[[NME]]''.{{cite web|title = A decade in music - 50 best albums of 2006 {{!}} NME.COM|url = https://www.nme.com/photos/a-decade-in-music-50-best-albums-of-2006/161055#/photo/47|website = NME|access-date = 2016-02-08|language = en-GB|last = NME.COM}} Their third studio album, ''[[It's Blitz!]]'', was released in March 2009. All three albums earned the band Grammy nominations for Best Alternative Music Album. Their fourth album, ''[[Mosquito (Yeah Yeah Yeahs album)|Mosquito]]'', came out in April 2013, and ''[[Cool It Down|Cool It Down]]'' followed in September 2022. ==History== ===Formation and ''Fever to Tell'' (1990s–2004)=== [[Karen O]] and [[Brian Chase]] first met as students at [[Oberlin College]] in Ohio in the late 1990s, where Chase was a jazz student at the conservatory. Karen then transferred to [[New York University]] and met [[Nick Zinner|Zinner]] in a local bar, where they formed an "instant connection." During this time, they also shared a loft with future members of the band [[Metric (band)|Metric]].{{cite web|url=http://ladygunn.com/music/emily-haines-of-metric-interview |title=YYYs shared a loft with Metric |date=28 November 2010 |publisher=Ladygunn.com |access-date=2011-10-09}} Orzolek and Zinner formed an acoustic duo called Unitard but soon decided to "shake things up a bit" by forming a "trashy, punky, grimy" band modeled after the art student, [[avant-punk]] bands Karen O was exposed to at Oberlin.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2006/feb/26/popandrock.yeahyeahyeahs|title=Lynsey Hansley talks to Yeah Yeah Yeahs| first=Lynsey| last=Hanley| date=February 26, 2006|work=The Guardian| access-date=2009-04-15}} After the drummer they initially recruited bowed out, Chase joined the line-up. The band wrote a slew of songs at their first rehearsal and soon wound up supporting [[The Strokes]] and [[The White Stripes]], earning a significant buzz for their arty and garage punk scene. In late 2001, the Yeah Yeah Yeahs released their [[Yeah Yeah Yeahs (EP)|self-titled debut EP]], which they recorded with [[Boss Hog]]'s Jerry Teel, on their own Shifty label.{{cite web| url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/Jerry+Teel| title=Jerry Teel| work=[[Discogs]]|access-date=2009-04-15}} Early the next year, they stepped into the international spotlight, appearing at [[South by Southwest]], touring the U.S. with [[Girls Against Boys]], and Europe with [[Jon Spencer Blues Explosion]], and headlining their own U.K. tour. [[Wichita Recordings]] distributed the group's EP in the U.K. and [[Touch and Go Records|Touch and Go]] reissued it in the States.{{cite web| url=http://www.mtv.com/music/artist/yeah_yeah_yeahs/artist.jhtml| title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs|publisher=mtv| access-date=2009-04-15}} In 2003, the band released their debut album, ''[[Fever to Tell]]'', which received several strong critical reviews and sold more than 750,000 copies worldwide. The album's third single, "[[Maps (Yeah Yeah Yeahs song)|Maps]]", received significant airplay on [[alternative rock|alternative]] radio. In 2010, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' ranked "Maps" as 386th in their list of the [[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of All Time|500 Greatest Songs of All Time]]. The video for their 2004 single "[[Y Control]]" was directed by [[Spike Jonze]]. In October 2004, the band released their first DVD, ''[[Tell Me What Rockers to Swallow]]''. The DVD included a concert filmed at [[The Fillmore]] in San Francisco, all of the band's music videos to date, and various interviews. Later the same year, they were featured in [[Scott Crary]]'s documentary ''[[Kill Your Idols (film)|Kill Your Idols]]''. In November 2009, ''[[NME]]'' rated ''Fever to Tell'' the No. 5 Best Album of the Decade.{{cite web |url=https://www.nme.com/news/the-strokes/48412 |title=The Strokes' 'Is This It' tops NME albums of the decade list |access-date=2009-11-17 |date=November 17, 2009 |work=NME News }} ===''Show Your Bones'' and ''Is Is'' EP (2005–2007)=== [[File:Karen O, Tim Festival.jpg|thumb|left|150px|upright|Karen O live at the Tim Festival in 2006]] The Yeah Yeah Yeahs' second album, ''[[Show Your Bones]]'', was released on March 28, 2006. [[Karen O]] told [[online zine]] [[Drowned in Sound]], "''[[Show Your Bones]]'' is what happens when you put your finger in a light socket", crediting "9-year old antigenius wonder-kid Drake Barrett for the insight."{{cite news|first=Colin |last=Roberts |url=http://drownedinsound.com/news/562122 |title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs LP and single details, yeah |work=[[Drowned In Sound]] |date=January 11, 2006 |access-date=2008-11-19}} The first single from the album, "[[Gold Lion]]", was released on 20 March 2006, reaching number 18 in the [[Official UK Singles Chart]]. It has been noted by Leah Greenblatt that "[[Gold Lion]]" sounds startlingly similar to "No New Tale To Tell" from 1980s alternative band [[Love and Rockets (band)|Love and Rockets]].{{cite news|last=Greenblatt |first=Leah |url=https://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1204700,00.html |title=Did The Red Hot Chili Peppers copy Tom Petty? |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=June 16, 2006 |issue=883 |access-date=2008-11-19}} The band toured throughout Europe and the United States during much of 2006, and also helped to curate an edition of the British [[All Tomorrow's Parties (music festival)|All Tomorrow's Parties]] festival. In December 2006, the album was named second best album of the year by ''[[NME]]'' magazine, and "Cheated Hearts" was voted 10th best song. ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine named ''Show Your Bones'' the 44th best album of 2006, while ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'' magazine ranked it number 31 on their 40 best albums of 2006. Yeah Yeah Yeahs' third EP, titled ''[[Is Is]]'', was released on July 24, 2007. It includes 5 previously unreleased songs and a short film, which was recorded and filmed at the [[Glasslands Gallery]] in Brooklyn, NY. The songs were written in 2004, during the Fever To Tell tour, and performed live often.{{cite news |url=http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/news/43606-yeah-yeah-yeahs-to-release-new-ep-of-old-songs |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080307024159/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/news/43606-yeah-yeah-yeahs-to-release-new-ep-of-old-songs |archive-date=March 7, 2008 |title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs to Release New EP of Old Songs |last=Maher |first=Dave |date=July 13, 2006 |work=Pitchfork |access-date=2009-09-17 |url-status=dead}} Three of the five tracks were featured on the ''[[Tell Me What Rockers to Swallow]]'' DVD. [[File:Yeah Yeah Yeahs at Glastonbury 2009.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Karen O and Nick Zinner performing at the [[Glastonbury Festival]], 2009]] ===''It's Blitz!'' (2008–2009)=== The Yeah Yeah Yeah's next album was released in March 2009 and titled ''[[It's Blitz!]]''.{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/34436-new-yeah-yeah-yeahs-album-iits-blitzi/|title=New Yeah Yeah Yeahs Album: It's Blitz| date=January 21, 2009| work=[[Pitchfork Media]]| author=Breihan, Tom| access-date=2009-04-15}} The band says the album sounds different from their previous ones but "still [sounds] like Yeah Yeah Yeahs". It was originally set to be released on April 13, but following an [[music leak|internet leak]] on February 22, {{cite web| url=http://diditleak.co.uk/?paged=2| title=Diditleak|publisher=Diditleak.co.uk| access-date=2009-04-15}} the band's label, Interscope, pulled the release date closer to reduce the leak's impact.{{cite web| url=https://www.nme.com/news/yeah-yeah-yeahs/43188| title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs to release album early due to leak| date=March 3, 2009|work=NME |access-date=2009-04-15}} The album spawned three singles: "[[Zero (Yeah Yeah Yeahs song)|Zero]]", "[[Heads Will Roll (song)|Heads Will Roll]]," and "[[Skeletons (Yeah Yeah Yeahs song)|Skeletons]]." ''It's Blitz!'' was named second best album of 2009 by ''[[Spin Magazine]]'' and third best by ''[[NME]]'', along with "[[Zero (Yeah Yeah Yeahs song)|Zero]]" from the album listed as the best track of the year by both.{{cite web|url=http://www.spin.com/gallery/40-best-albums-2009?page=39|title=The 40 Best Albums of 2009|date=December 7, 2009|work=Spin|access-date=December 17, 2009}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/list/50-best-albums-of-2009/159978/|title=50 Best Albums of 2009|work=NME|date=2 December 2009|access-date=December 13, 2009}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/list/50-best-tracks-of-2009/159979|title=50 Best Tracks of 2009|work=NME|date=2 December 2009|access-date=December 13, 2009}}{{cite web|url=https://www.spin.com/2010/01/20-best-songs-2009/|title=The 20 Best Songs of 2009|author=Spin Staff|date=December 7, 2009|work=Spin|access-date=December 17, 2009}} ===''Mosquito'' and hiatus (2011–2016)=== On December 9, 2011, Karen O reported to ''NME'' that she had been working on new music with the band, hinting a new album was possibly in the making.{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/yeah-yeah-yeahs/60897|title=Karen O: 'I have been working on new Yeah Yeah Yeahs music'|publisher=NME.com|access-date=2012-12-12}} On January 14, 2013, it was announced via their official Facebook page that the new album would be titled ''[[Mosquito (Yeah Yeah Yeahs album)|Mosquito]]''. It was released on April 16, of the same year.{{cite web|title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs's Facebook|website=[[Facebook]]|url=https://www.facebook.com/yeahyeahyeahs/posts/585043118189140/ |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/facebook/20460316308/585043118189140 |archive-date=2022-02-26 |url-access=limited|access-date=January 14, 2013}}{{cbignore}} The album features production by [[TV on the Radio]]'s [[Dave Sitek]], [[Nick Launay]], and LCD Soundsystem's [[James Murphy (electronic musician)|James Murphy]].{{cite web|title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs Go 'Raw, Chaotic, Dreamy' on April Album 'Mosquito'|date=14 January 2013|url=https://www.spin.com/2013/01/yeah-yeah-yeahs-mosquito-new-album-april-karen-o/|access-date=January 14, 2013}} The first single, "[[Sacrilege (song)|Sacrilege]]", was released on 15 February 2013.{{cite web|title= Yeah Yeah Yeahs Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/YYYs/status/304324067857670145|access-date=February 20, 2013}} "Despair" was released as the second single on July 23, 2013.{{cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/despair-single/id673431285 |title=iTunes - Music - Despair - Single - Yeah Yeah Yeahs |date=January 2013 |publisher=[[iTunes Store]] |access-date=July 31, 2013}} [[File:Yeah Yeah Yeahs Ventura.jpg|thumb|left|200px|The Yeah Yeah Yeahs playing in [[Ventura, California]], 2013]] In December 2014, the Yeah Yeah Yeahs went on hiatus.{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/karen-o/81883 |title=Karen O says Yeah Yeah Yeahs 'are on a bit of a hiatus' |publisher=Nme.com |date=2014-12-22 |access-date=2015-10-27}} In 2016, the band received writing credits on the [[Beyoncé]] single "[[Hold Up (song)|Hold Up]]".{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/7348295/beyonce-lemonade-credit-hold-up-ezra-koenig-yeah-yeah-yeahs-vampire-weekend|title=Here's How Ezra Koenig Squeezed the Yeah Yeah Yeahs' 'Maps' Into Beyonce's 'Lemonade'|website=Billboard.com|date=26 April 2016|access-date=1 October 2017}} [[File:Yeah Yeah Yeahs Corona Capital Guadalajara.jpg|thumb|200px|The Yeah Yeah Yeahs performing at Corona Capital Guadalajara, 2019]] ===Return in 2017=== On June 20, 2017, the Yeah Yeah Yeahs announced that they would be headlining the Austin "Sound on Sound" festival on 10 November, adding: "Watch for more news coming soon"{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/yeah-yeah-yeahs-announce-first-concert-in-four-years-w488815|title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs Announce First Concert in Four Years|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=2017-06-21}} The Sound on Sound festival was subsequently cancelled. {{cite web|last1=Stith|first1=Deborah|title=Sound on Sound Fest 2017 cancelled after main investor pulls out|url=https://www.austin360.com/entertainment/music/sound-sound-fest-2017-canceled-due-recent-roadblocks/8UepbahmfboYUskx0kHmnN/|website=austin360}} On May 26, 2018, the Yeah Yeah Yeahs played at All Points Festival in Victoria Park, London.{{cite web|title=Why We're So Excited About Yeah Yeah Yeahs' UK Comeback This Weekend |url=https://diymag.com/2018/05/22/yeah-yeah-yeahs-all-points-east-2018-get-excited-about |website=diymag.com |date=22 May 2018 |access-date=9 July 2020}} ===Reissue of ''Fever to Tell''=== The Yeah Yeah Yeahs released a deluxe remastering of their debut album ''Fever to Tell'' on October 20, 2017, through Interscope / UMe. It features previously unreleased demos, B-sides, and other rarities from the era.{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/yeah-yeah-yeahs-announce-fever-to-tell-reissue-share-unreleased-song-listen/|title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs Announce Fever to Tell Reissue, Share Unreleased Song: Listen {{!}} Pitchfork|website=pitchfork.com|date=26 September 2017|language=en|access-date=2017-09-27}} In a press release, the band announced, "A friend of a friend kept asking if we were ever gonna put ''Fever to Tell'' out on vinyl as it hasn't been on vinyl in 10 years. That's not right. So here it is on vinyl for the first time in 10 years plus a time capsule of photos, demos (1st ever recorded,) a mini film documenting our near downfall and other fun memorabilia, from the turn of the century NYC, made with love + the usual blood, sweat + tears of Yeah Yeah Yeahs." To celebrate the reissue, the band performed a small series of shows in October and November at [[The Fonda Theatre]] in Los Angeles, California, the [[Fox Oakland Theatre]] in Oakland, California, and [[Kings Theatre (Brooklyn)|Kings Theatre]] in Brooklyn, New York. ===''Cool It Down'' (2022)=== In June 2022, the band announced that they would be releasing the album ''[[Cool It Down]]'' on September 30, making it their first record in nine years. They released the first single, "Spitting Off the Edge of the World", featuring [[Perfume Genius]], on June 1.{{Cite news |last=Gotrich |first=Lars |date=2022-06-07 |title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs (feat. Perfume Genius), 'Spitting Off the Edge of the World' |language=en |work=NPR |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/now-playing/2022/06/07/1103490152/yeah-yeah-yeahs-feat-perfume-genius-spitting-off-the-edge-of-the-world |access-date=2022-07-08}} On September 29, 2022, the band performed their second single, "Burning", on ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' as part of the show's weeklong residency at the [[Brooklyn Academy of Music]].{{Cite web |last=Tinoco |first=Armando |last2= |first2= |date=2022-09-24 |title='Jimmy Kimmel Live!' Sets Guest Lineup as Late-Night Host Goes Back to Brooklyn for a Week |url=https://deadline.com/2022/09/jimmy-kimmel-live-guests-lineup-brooklyn-1235126334/ |access-date=2022-09-30 |website=Deadline }}{{Cite web |date=2022-09-30 |title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs' Give Volcanic 'Kimmel' Performance & Release New Album 'Cool It Down': Watch & Stream |url=https://www.stereogum.com/2201284/watch-yeah-yeah-yeahs-volcanic-kimmel-performance-stream-their-new-album-cool-it-down/news/ |access-date=2022-09-30 |website=Stereogum }} ==Musical style== The Yeah Yeahs' style has been described as "an art-rock trio who made an edgy post-punk, dancefloor-friendly racket that mixed up [[Blondie (band)|Blondie]], [[The Pretenders|Pretenders]], and [[Siouxsie and the Banshees]]".{{cite web |last=Gross |first=Joe |url=https://www.spin.com/2013/04/yeah-yeah-yeahs-mosquito-interscope/ |title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs, 'Mosquito' (Interscope) |work=Spin |date=April 15, 2013 |access-date=November 8, 2015}} ==Awards and nominations== '''Antville Music Video Awards''' {{award table}} |- | rowspan="2" | 2006 | rowspan="2" | "Gold Lion" | Best Cinematography | {{nom}} |- Control]]" | Direction | style="background:#FFBF00"| Yellow Pencil |- | rowspan=2|2014 | rowspan=2|"[[Sacrilege (song)|Sacrilege]]" | Cinematography | style="background:#BF8040"| Wood Pencil |- | 2010|publisher=MTV}} | rowspan="3"| [[Grammy Award for Best Alternative Music Album|Best Alternative Music Album]] | {{nom}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[49th Annual Grammy Awards|2007]] | ''[[Show Your Bones]]''{{cite web|url=http://www2.grammy.com/GRAMMY_Awards/49th_show/list.aspx#05 |title=49th Annual Grammy Awards Winners List |publisher=Grammy Awards |access-date=April 29, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20061220160454/http://www.grammy.com/GRAMMY_Awards/49th_Show/list.aspx |archive-date=December 20, 2006 }} | {{nom}} |- | International Band |{{nom}} |- | 2011 | [[Karen O]] | Hottest Woman |{{won}} {{end}} '''New York Music Awards''' {{award table}} |- | 2011 | "[[Heads Will Roll (song)|Heads Will Roll]]" ([[A-Trak]] {{nom}} | rowspan=2|{{Cite web|url=https://www.anketazebrik.cz/historie/2010-2004/|title=2010-2004 – Anketa Žebřík|website=Anketazebrik.cz|access-date=8 April 2022}} |- | Themselves | Best International Discovery | {{nom}} {{end}} ==Discography== {{main|Yeah Yeah Yeahs discography}} '''Studio albums''' * ''[[Fever to Tell]]'' (2003) * ''[[Show Your Bones]]'' (2006) * ''[[It's Blitz!]]'' to interviews, photos, etc. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090712052109/http://www.exclaim.ca/articles/multiarticlesub.aspx?csid1=79&csid2=778&fid1=1003 "Yeah Yeah Yeahs: The Love Cats"],
